body: @jiazhai sorry if it's supposed to be obvious but I don't know how to rerun integration tests.
run java8 tests

Oh also, @jiazhai happy to add a test, I just didn't see any existing tests for this functionality, either at the unit level of the controller actions or at the more "integration" style tests of exercising the http calls.

If you can provide me with some info of how I should go about that, happy to add a test
run java8 tests

I also implemented this commit https://github.com/instructure/pulsar/commit/a5bb666d5bb2f33099e639672e3c2e56fef2c03d (no pull request open yet) that does not use the null or implement the clear method. It was small enough that I just wanted to see what both would look like.

I think that the ugliness of the `-1` being ambiguous is not awesome for the one edge case of want to override a namespace to disable offloading, but can be worked around by using any other negative value instead.
run java8 tests

thanks！

there is a bug in apachepulsar/pulsar-dashboard:2.4.2 docker image, 
/usr/lib/postgresql/9.6/bin/initdb  - > /usr/lib/postgresql/11/bin/initdb  for /pulsar/init-postgres.sh
perhaps you can set image tag to other version, apachepulsar/pulsar-dashboard:2.4.1 works fine for me.

There seems to be a problem upgrading to 11. The postgresql version in the container has not been upgraded. First, the 11 version of postgresql https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/1419483da24215c49b1d61006c1f56b494782f67/docker/pulsar-standalone/Dockerfile should be installed.

@frejonb I may not understand this issue. what do you mean by "bring down" all the consumers?
From the example situation, the consumer got OOM is because the timeout too long, and hold too many messages in consumer?
run java8 tests

Thanks @addisonj for the detailed explanation. Comparing with "Long", your later change https://github.com/instructure/pulsar/commit/a5bb666d5bb2f33099e639672e3c2e56fef2c03d  is better from my point of view. as you suggested we could choose another -2 for this case.
regarding the test, could we reuse [NamespacesTest.java](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/test/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/admin/NamespacesTest.java) ?

@jiazhai the reason a consumer can get OOM killed is because it received a "bad message". The processing of this bad message can lead to an application crash (the consumer) for many reasons. For example if the processing of the bad message requires too much RAM, then it may be OOM killed. But the application can also be unresponsive for many reasons. 

The particular cause is not important here. My point is that the motivation for implementing DLQ was to prevent this https://github.com/apache/pulsar/issues/189, https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/2400. But in the situation when the consumer is not responsive, the redelivery count is not increased after ack timeout and therefore there's no way to get rid of the message.

@codelipenghui I've disabled the batch, but see exactly the same behaviour. Have you tried reproducing several times on the same topic/subscription? I've just checked without batches and it worked once, on another run I see the same issue I described. When I stop consumers and start them again without producing new messages I get the missing messages, so my runs were
1. Produced and consumed - worked
2. Produced and consumed again - worked for 1 partition, only 1 message was delivered from second partition
3. Consumed again - all the rest messages were delivered

I have test by using your java code.

1.start 2 consumers
2.send some messages by using pulsar-client produce(50 messages)

Looks like the problem is not on client side, since the same behavior is seen on Java client 2.4.1, 2.4.2 and .net client that I'm developing.

I have also recently checked a problem with the consumer stopping consumption. If you can easily reproduce, could you help to make a broker log(in debug level) and heap dump of broker(which owned the stop consume topic). Other users have also found this problem, but difficult to reproduce.

And the internal stats shows there 2 waiting cursors, this looks problematic since there are backlogs of the subscription.

BTW, currently we used 2.4.0 , seems the problem has not happened yet.

Probably cursors are from other subscriptions, I've cut them for brevity, adding full output. I don't think I can change debug level for broker, but I can take the dump, can you help me with that? Can't find a tool to see the processes on the node, top and ps are unavailable

I found this thread as I was having similar exceptions.  I received consistent failures while logged into wifi but seemed a bit more stable when hard connected to the network.  It would still crash, however, when plugged into the network.  Looking through the logs I noticed that the hostname of my mac is being used as a connection for some service in standalone mode (and I assume non-standalone mode).  I found my hostname was not in DNS.  I added my mac's hostname to /etc/hosts and everything started up fine and is stable.

@jiazhai okay, pushed up the alternate implementation to here and also added a test that I think covers the functionality pretty well.

Please let me know if there is anything else you need here!

@sijie @codelipenghui PTAL:)

@jiazhai @frejonb If i understand correctly, the problem is the redelivery count not increase but the message was actually redelivered since only increase redelivery count when client send redelivery request.  Currently, we maintain the redelivery count at broker side, i think we'd fix it at broker side, the brokers need to guarantee the correctness of redelivery count cannot completely depends on client redelivery un-ack messages requests.

@frejonb Does this can solve your problem?

Might have something to do with the Broker seeing no initialized Bookie:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/588573/71207749-41b21600-22b0-11ea-95a6-d8bdee659e1d.png)

The Bookies in my cluster eventually initialize fine, so this is probably a init race issue.
The Brokers also recover after a few restarts (they are hitting an error where they discover their ZK node entry from the previous run and bail out, so that has to time out first, or something.)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/588573/71207903-92297380-22b0-11ea-92bc-9531a6b02c55.png)

Basically, if functions are enabled, the Brokers init should be delayed until Bookies are fully initialized.

(Ideally (as with waiting for ZK init), no Bash scripts would be necessary to facilitate this delay, and instead the cluster components would have this logic in the Java code.)

@huangdx0726 Thanks your fix, but I think this fix seems incorrect. The download link on this page http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/2.3.0/standalone/ should be apache-pulsar-2.3.0-bin.tar.gz instead of rpm package download link, so I think the following code should be added and then the `downloadPageUrl` function should be fixed to support the download of the old version.

```
     binaryReleaseUrl(`${v}`),
      connectorReleaseUrl(`${v}`),
      // add this function
      offloaderReleaseUrl(`${v}`),
      prestoPulsarReleaseUrl(`${latestVersion}`),
      // Fix this function for support old version
      downloadPageUrl(),
      rpmReleaseUrl(`${v}`, ""),
      rpmReleaseUrl(`${v}`, "-debuginfo"),
      rpmReleaseUrl(`${v}`, "-devel"),
      debReleaseUrl(`${v}`, ""),
      debReleaseUrl(`${v}`, "-dev"),
```
run java8 tests
